case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab v. Pandit Thakurdas Bhargava

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 236 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 236 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 3, 1953 of Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 7/1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1953, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 7/1952.

facts.text: Certificate of fitness granted by Punjab High Court on December 28, 1953 under s.66A(2) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness granted under the provisions of sub-s. 2 of s. 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, by the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab then sitting at Simla. The certificate is dated December 28, 1953

facts.text: Pandit Thakurdas Bhargava, advocate of Hissar, assessed to income tax for assessment year 1946-47 on total income of Rs. 58,475 in account year 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: For the assesment year 1946-47, one Pandit Thakurdas Bhargava, an advocate of Hissar and respondent before us, was assessed to income tax on a total assessable income of Rs. 58,475/- in the account year 1945-46.

facts.text: Rs. 32,500 received by respondent in July 1945 for defending accused in Farrukhnagar case included in assessable income.

anchor.surface_text: This sum included the amount of Rs. 32,500/stated to have been received by the respondent in July, 1945 for defending the accused persons in a case known as the Farrukbnagar case.

facts.text: Assessee claimed Rs. 32,500 was given in trust for charity, not professional income.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed that the said amount of Rs. 32,500/- was number a part of his professional income, because the amount was given to him in trust for charity.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 32,500 as professional income of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: This claim of the assessee was number accepted by the Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 32,500 as professional income, trust created later by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: number by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who heard the appeal from the order of the Income-tax Officer. Both these officers held that the assessee had received the amount of Rs. 32,500/- as his professional income and the trust which the assessee later created by a deed of Trust dated August 6, 1945, did number change the nature or character of the receipt as professional income of the assessee

facts.text: Trust deed dated August 6, 1945 created by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: deed of Trust dated August 6, 1945,

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal deleted Rs. 32,500 from assessment, holding it received on behalf of trust.

anchor.surface_text: From the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner a further appeal was carried to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi Branch. ... In this view, we delete the sum of Rs. 32,500/- from the assessment.

facts.text: Tribunal stated case to High Court under s.66 on question whether Rs.32,500 was professional income or trust money.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the Tribunal for stating a case to the High Court on the question of law which arose out of the order of the Tribunal. ... Whether the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee in the circumstances set out in the trust deed later executed by him on August 6, 1945, was his professional income taxable in his hands, or was it money received by him on behalf of a trust and number in his capacity as an individual.

facts.text: Punjab High Court answered question in favor of assessee on August 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: A case was accordingly stated to the High Court under s. 66 of the Indian Income- tax Act, and the High Court by its judgment dated August 3, 1953, answered the question in favour of the assessee,

facts.text: In trust deed, assessee stated relatives and accused promised Rs.40,000 for charitable trust to conduct Farrukhnagar case (Crown v. Chuttan Lal etc.).

anchor.surface_text: In the Farrukh- Dagar, district Gurgaon case, Crown v. Chuttan Lal etc., the relatives and the accused expressed a strong desire to get the case companyducted by me during its trial. At last on their persistence and promise that they would provide me with Rs. 40,000/- for charitable purposes and I would create a public charitable trust thereof I agreed to companyduct the case.

facts.text: Accused and relatives gave Rs.32,500 to assessee for charity and trust, deposited in bank.

anchor.surface_text: The case is number over. The accused and their relatives have given me Rs. 32,500/- for charity and creating a trust. The said amount has been deposited in the Bank.

facts.text: Tribunal found assessee unwilling to accept brief initially, persuaded by bar members and locals on understanding accused would provide Rs.40,000 for trust assessee would create.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accepted as companyrect the statements of the respondent that he was at first unwilling to accept the brief in the Farrukhnagar case he was then persuaded to accept it at the request of some members of the Bar and some influential local people on the understanding, as the respondent put it, that the accused persons of that case would-provide Rs. 40,000/- for a charitable trust which the respondent would create.

facts.text: Sum of Rs.32,500 paid by or on behalf of accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the sum of Rs. 32,500/- was paid by or on behalf of the accused persons,

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rs.32,500 was professional income of assessee, no trust created at time of receipt.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the question raised in this case can be decided by a very short answer, and that answer is that from the facts found by the Tribunal the proper legal inference is that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- paid to the assessee was his professional income at the time when it was paid and numbertrust or obligation in the nature of a trust was created at that time,

facts.text: Assessee reserved professional income after June 1944 for taxes and charity.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent stated in the trust deed that he had decreased his legal practice for the last few years and had reserved his professional income accruing after June 1944 for payment of taxes and charity.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Supreme Court on July 27, 1960 by K. DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, K. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant. C. Chatterjee and S. K. Sekhri, for the respondent. 1960. July 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-

facts.text: Appeal allowed by Supreme Court, High Court judgment set aside, Rs.32,500 held taxable as professional income.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court. The answer to the question is in favour of the appellant, namely, that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was his professional income taxable in his hands.

facts.text: Assessee stated in affidavit agreement that accused would provide Rs.40,000 for trust he would create.

anchor.surface_text: Even in his affidavit the assessee had stated that it was agreed that the accused would provide Rs. 40,000/- for a charitable trust which I would create in case I defend them, on an absolutely clear and express understanding that the money would number be used for any private and personal purposes.
sub-s. 2 of s. 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

arguments.claim: Principle of Bejoy Singh applies via overriding title or obligation before income accrues; supported by cases involving decrees, awards, wills, deeds.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent has referred us to a number of decisions where the principle laid down in Bejoy Singh Dudhurias Case  1  was applied, and has companytended that where there is an allocation of a sum out of revenue as a result of an overriding title or obligation before it becomes income in the hands of the assessee, the allocation may be the result of a decree of a companyrt, an arbitration award or even the provisions of a will or deed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of a decree of a companyrt, an arbitration award or even the provisions of a will or deed. In view o

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to consider as no overriding obligation existed.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rightly pointed out that if the accused persons had themselves resolved to create a charitable trust in memory of the professional aid rendered to them by the appellant and had made the assessee trustee for the money so paid to him for that purpose, it companyld, perhaps, be argued that the money paid was earmarked for charity ab initio but of this there was numberindication anywhere.

holdings.text: from the facts found by the Tribunal the proper legal inference is that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- paid to the assessee was his professional income at the time when it was paid and no trust or obligation in the nature of a trust was created at that time, and when the assessee created a trust by the trust deed of August 6, 1945, he applied part of his professional income as trust property.

anchor.surface_text: from the facts found by the Tribunal the proper legal inference is that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- paid to the assessee was his professional income at the time when it was paid and no trust or obligation in the nature of a trust was created at that time, and when the assessee created a trust by the trust deed of August 6, 1945, he applied part of his professional income as trust property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts found by Tribunal show assessee received payment for services; no imperative obligation or trust by payers at payment; trust deed recitals confirm assessee reserved and applied his income to create trust later.

holdings.text: the principle laid down by the Privy Council in Bejoy Singh Dudhuria's case has no application.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the true conclusion as we hold it to be, then the principle laid down by the Privy Council in Bejoy Singh Dudhuria's case has no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No overriding obligation or trust created by payers at time of payment, distinguishing facts from Bejoy Singh where obligation diverted income before accrual.

holdings.text: a trust may be created by any language sufficient to show the intention and no technical words are necessary. A trust may even be created by the use of words which are primarily words of condition, but such words will constitute a trust only where the requisites of a trust are present, namely, where there are purposes independent of the donee to which the subject-matter of the gift is required to be applied and an obligation on the donee to satisfy those purposes.

anchor.surface_text: It is indeed true, as has been observed by the High Court, that a trust may be created by any language sufficient to show the intention and no technical words are necessary. A trust may even be created by the use of words which are primarily words of condition, but such words will constitute a trust only where the requisites of a trust are present, namely, where there are purposes independent of the donee to which the subject-matter of the gift is required to be applied and an obligation on the donee to satisfy those purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payers used no imperative words creating obligation; assessee proposed trust himself; requisites absent as no independent obligation imposed on assessee at payment.

holdings.text: the assessee created a trust by the deed of trust dated August 6, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The position is clarified beyond any doubt by the statements made in the trust deed of August 6, 1945. The assessee said therein that he was reserving his professional income as an advocate accruing after June, 1944 for payments of taxes and charity and, accordingly, when he received his professional income in the Farrukhnagar case he created a charitable trust out of the money so received.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trust deed recitals and affidavit state assessee reserved his income after June 1944 for charity and created trust therefrom; no indication payers created trust or imposed obligation.

holdings.text: there was no trust nor any legal obligation imposed on the assessee by the persons who paid the money, at the time when the money was received, which prevented the amount from becoming the professional income of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it has been contended that the inference which the Tribunal and the High Court drew is not the proper legal inference which flows from the facts found, and according to the learned Attorney-General who appeared for the appellant the proper legal inference is that the amount was received by the assessee as his professional income in respect of which he later created a trust by the deed of trust dated August 6, 1945. He has submitted that there was no trust nor any legal obligation imposed on the assessee by the persons who paid the money, at the time when the money was received, which prevented the amount from becoming the professional income of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if trust existed later, money not diverted before becoming income; must be pre-accrual diversion, not post-receipt application.

holdings.text: the correct answer to the question referred to the High Court is that the amount of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was professional income taxable in his hands.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the correct answer to the question referred to the High Court is that the amount of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was professional income taxable in his hands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receipt for professional services taxable upon receipt; subsequent voluntary application to charity irrelevant.

holdings.text: we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court. The answer to the question is in favour of the appellant, namely, that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was his professional income taxable in his hands.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court. The answer to the question is in favour of the appellant, namely, that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was his professional income taxable in his hands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in inferring trust created by payers; proper inference supports taxability as professional income.

holdings.text: if the accused persons had themselves resolved to create a charitable trust in memory of the professional aid rendered to them by the appellant and had made the assessee trustee for the money so paid to him for that purpose, it could, perhaps, be argued that the money paid was earmarked for charity ab initio but of this there was no indication anywhere.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rightly pointed out that if the accused persons had themselves resolved to create a charitable trust in memory of the professional aid rendered to them by the appellant and had made the assessee trustee for the money so paid to him for that purpose, it could, perhaps, be argued that the money paid was earmarked for charity ab initio but of this there was no indication anywhere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical scenario not applicable to facts; mere observation on possible argument if facts different.

edges.explanation: h3 states requirements for trust creation by language showing intention, grounding c4's application to no trust by payers

anchor.surface_text: It is indeed true, as has been observed by the High Court, that a trust may be created by any language sufficient to show the intention and no technical words are necessary. A trust may even be created by the use of words which are primarily words of condition, but such words will constitute a trust only where the requisites of a trust are present, namely, where there are purposes independent of the donee to which the subject-matter of the gift is required to be applied and an obligation on the donee to satisfy those purposes.

Accordingly, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court. The answer to the question is in favour of the appellant, namely, that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was his professional income taxable in his hands.
ukhnagar case he created a charitable trust out of the money so received. The clear statement in the trust deed, a statement accepted as companyrect b

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that assessee created trust on August 6, 1945 (later per i1), supports no prior diversion under c3

anchor.surface_text: The position is clarified beyond any doubt by the statements made in the trust deed of August 6, 1945. The assessee said therein that he was reserving his professional income as an advocate accruing after June, 1944 for payments of taxes and charity and, accordingly, when he received his professional income in the Farrukhnagar case he created a charitable trust out of the money so received.

Accordingly, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court. The answer to the question is in favour of the appellant, namely, that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was his professional income taxable in his hands.

edges.explanation: h5 finding no pre-receipt trust/obligation supports c6 diversion vs application
h5 no trust/obligation at receipt supports h1 inference of professional income

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it has been contended that the inference which the Tribunal and the High Court drew is not the proper legal inference which flows from the facts found, and according to the learned Attorney-General who appeared for the appellant the proper legal inference is that the amount was received by the assessee as his professional income in respect of which he later created a trust by the deed of trust dated August 6, 1945. He has submitted that there was no trust nor any legal obligation imposed on the assessee by the persons who paid the money, at the time when the money was received, which prevented the amount from becoming the professional income of the assessee.

Accordingly, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court. The answer to the question is in favour of the appellant, namely, that the sum of Rs. 32,500/- received by the assessee was his professional income taxable in his hands.
